Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hygroscopic Properties of Aerosol Organics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Aerosols contribute to the Earth's radiation balance directly by absorbing and scattering light and indirectly by nucleating cloud droplets which increase planetary albedo. Both effects depend on hygroscopic growth, but the contribution of organics to aerosol hygroscopicity is not well understood--limiting efforts to model those effects. This study will address several important questions regarding aerosol hygroscopicity through field measurements, laboratory experiments, and modeling: (1) What is the contribution of water-soluble organic carbon (WSOC) to hygroscopic growth under sub- and super-saturated conditions?; (2) What are the chemical and physical properties of WSOC?; and (3) How well can Köhler theory and thermodynamic equilibrium modeling account for observed hydroscopic growth and cloud condensation nucleus (CCN) activity of mixed inorganic and organic aerosols? To answer these questions, aerosol samples will be collected at the Desert Research Institute's high-elevation Storm Peak Laboratory (SPL) during summer. Detailed inorganic and organic composition of the samples will be measured with state-of-the-art analytical techniques to identify heretofore unspeciated high molecular weight WSOC. Water extracts of the samples and isolated WSOC will be re-aerosolized to directly measure their contribution to hygroscopic growth and CCN activity. Measured growth factors and CCN activity will be reconciled using Köhler theory and structure-based thermodynamic activity models. The results of this work will improve ability to simulate hygroscopic growth for aerosols of mixed inorganic and organic composition.

The explicit treatment of high molecular weight WSOC compounds produced in this project will be incorporated into the on-line version of the E-AIM thermodynamic equilibrium model for use by researchers and students worldwide. Ultimately, the project's results will provide information that can be incorporated into large-scale climate models to better predict direct and indirect aerosol radiative effects, such as hygroscopic-growth curves for water soluble organics and parameterizations of Köhler theory for aerosols of different inorganic and organic composition. The research will be incorporated into student projects as part of the Geoscience Research at Storm Peak (GRASP) activity, which engages students from underrepresented groups. During the winter of 2010, SPL will also host atmospheric science field courses for several universities. The project will allow the students taking these courses to work together with project researchers during the field deployment. Graduate undergraduate students from the involved research groups participate in laboratory experiments, data analysis, and publication of the results.

Collaborative Research: Hygroscopic Properties of Aerosol Organics

Lynn R. Mazzoleni1,2

1Department of Chemistry, Michigan Technological University, Houghton, MI 49931, USA

2Michigan Technological University, Atmospheric Sciences Program, Houghton, MI 49931, USA

 

The composition of the aerosol organic compounds is highly complex, due to the wide number of ambient reactions. This complexity has greatly hindered our scientific understanding of the chemical nature of the organic aerosol since up to 80% of the organic fraction, particularly at remote sites, is classified as unidentified. In this research, we focused on the detailed molecular composition of ambient aerosol collected at the Storm Peak Laboratory, a remote mountain top site in northwestern Colorado. Using ultrahigh resolution mass spectrometry, we observed a complex mixture of over 4000 molecular formulas. The overall composition was highly influenced by the regional coniferous forest, yielding substantial contributions of secondary organic aerosol from the oxidation of biogenic terpenes. Overall, were observed the composition to be moderately to highly oxidized. Using an isoabundance scale for the relative abundances of each subgroup (Figure 1), we observed the high abundance CHO compounds to have an O:C range of 0.3–0.7. The high abundance CHNO compounds have a similar H:C range, but a wider O:C range. Similarly, high abundance CHOS compounds have a similar O:C range, but a higher H:C range. The high abundance CHNOS compounds are more diverse with respect to H:C and O:C ranges. The increased O:C ratios for the N and S containing formulas indicate that a substantial fraction of the N and S are oxidized and may be in the form of NO, NO2, NO3, SO2, SO3 and SO4 functional groups. This is consistent with observations of organonitrates, organosulfates and nitrooxyorganosulfates in atmospheric aerosol reported in previous studies, however the high number density of those compounds has not been shown previously.

We then studied the functional groups of hundreds of compounds using ultrahigh resolution tandem mass spectrometry. Precursor and production ion relationships were determined in this work by looking for the expected neutral losses. Due to the complex nature of the organic aerosol components, we observed considerable isobaric complexity at all of the typical neutral loss masses. We observed high percentages of components to be multi-functional due to observations of multiple neutral losses. As expected from the elemental ratios, polar functional groups such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, nitrate and sulfate groups were observed with high frequencies. Furthermore, very high percentages of compounds contained multiple polar functional groups. We observed approximately 70%, 50% and 35% of the CHO, CHNO and CHOS compounds to have both carboxyl and hydroxyl functional groups. Nitrate or sulfate functional groups were observed with very high frequencies (75%, 55% and 70%) for the CHNO, CHOS and CHNOS compounds. In addition, hydroxyl or carboxyl groups were indicated for at least 50% of the studied CHNO and CHOS compounds. These findings are consistent with ambient secondary organic aerosol of biogenic hydrocarbons and indicate significant potential for moderate contributions to aerosol hygroscopicity (water-uptake). 

A key broader impact of this research pertains to an improved understanding of the climate-relevant properties of atmospheric aerosol.
